byline.contributor: Jonathan M. Katz reported from Chapel Hill, N.C., and Richard Pérez-Peña from New York. Laurie Goodstein and Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting from New York.
byline.original: By JONATHAN M. KATZ and RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

abstract: Police say shootings of University of North Carolina students Yusor Mohammad Abu-Salha, Deah Shaddy Barakat and Razan Mohammad Abu-Salha in Chapel Hill appear to be motivated by parking dispute with neighbor Craig Stephen Hicks; family and friends of victims, however, say it was hate crime triggered by their Muslim faith; Hicks is charged with first-degree murder.
lead_paragraph: Craig Stephen Hicks, 46, was charged with first-degree murder in the Chapel Hill, N.C., shooting. The police cited a parking dispute, but friends wondered if the victims’ faith played a role.

headline.main: In Chapel Hill Shooting of 3 Muslims, a Question of Motive
headline.print_headline: In Killing of 3 Muslims, a Question of Motive

snippet: Craig Stephen Hicks, 46, was charged with first-degree murder in the Chapel Hill, N.C., shooting. The police cited a parking dispute, but friends wondered if the victims’ faith played a role.
